protocol_name: Code: Discovery of regulatory motifs in Labyrinthulomycete genomes
protocol_name_html: Code: Discovery of regulatory motifs in Labyrinthulomycete genomes
description: To develop broadly useful methods for the genetic manipulation of Labyrinthulomycetes, it is essential to understand the similarities and differences in regulation of gene expression among them. Toward this end we have used FIMO from the MEME suite (http://meme-suite.org/doc/fimo.html) to identify motifs similar to yeast transcription factor binding sites in each of the three available genome sequences: Aplanochytrium kerguelense PBS07, Schizochytrium aggregatum ATCC 28209, and Aurantiochytrium limacinum ATCC MYA-1381. We then make logograms to illustrate yeast-like GAL4 binding sites in each of the three genomes.

groups.group_name: Protist Research to Optimize Tools in Genetics (PROT-G)

(in further steps, any such genome data will be called genome.fasta)

components.data:
We scanned the genomes using Position Weight Matrices for putative transcription factor binding sties defined for budding yeast, Saccharomyces cerevisae. 

We used motif file SwissRegulon_s_cer.meme obtained from http://meme-suite.org/doc/download.html
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
We scanned the genomes using Position Weight Matrices for putative transcription factor binding sties defined for budding yeast, Saccharomyces cerevisae. 

We used motif file SwissRegulon_s_cer.meme obtained from http://meme-suite.org/doc/download.html

components.data:
We used fimo from meme_4.11.1 (http://meme-suite.org/doc/download.html) to scan each genome for motif matches.

The output from this scan for these three genomes is available at: http://commons.library.stonybrook.edu/inter-data/1/

components.data:
This creates an index file, and then a genome_File using samtools.

note: if there are blank lines in the fasta file, remove them (e.g. in vim use :g/^$/d ). Otherwise, samtools will produce an error.
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
This creates an index file, and then a genome_File using samtools.

note: if there are blank lines in the fasta file, remove them (e.g. in vim use :g/^$/d ). Otherwise, samtools will produce an error.

components.data: Optional step: Create a genome file in samtools
components.name: Section

source_data.section: Optional step: Create a genome file in samtools

source_data.name:
samtools faidx genome.fasta
awk -v OFS='\t' {'print $1,$2'} genome.fasta.fai > genomeFile.txt

components.data:
Use bedtools to retrieve flanking sequence 1kb upstream of the ATG.

In these genomes, we can grep the bed file for annotations that contain Exon Number 1, which includes the ATG. This is likely to differ according to the details of your genome annotation.

Partial genes at the beginning of a contig will create annotations from 0 to 0; these should be removed.
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Use bedtools to retrieve flanking sequence 1kb upstream of the ATG.

In these genomes, we can grep the bed file for annotations that contain Exon Number 1, which includes the ATG. This is likely to differ according to the details of your genome annotation.

Partial genes at the beginning of a contig will create annotations from 0 to 0; these should be removed.

components.data: Retrieve promoter sequences 1kb upstream of coding sequences
components.name: Section

source_data.section: Retrieve promoter sequences 1kb upstream of coding sequences

source_data.name:
bedtools flank -i GeneCatalog.bed -g genomeFile.txt -l 1000 -r 0 -s > GeneCatalog_genes_1kbupstream.bed
grep "exonNumber 1$" GeneCatalog_genes_1kbupstream.bed >GeneCatalog_genes_1kbupstreamExon1.bed

#optional: remove annotations that go from 0 to 0
grep -v -P '0\t0\t.\t.' GeneCatalog_genes_1kbupstreamExon1.bed >GeneCatalog_genes_1kbupstreamExon1no0.bed

bedtools getfasta -fi genome.fasta -bed GeneCatalog_genes_1kbupstreamExon1no0.bed -fo GeneCatalog_genes_1kbupstreamExon1.bed.fa

source_data.name: gff2bed < GeneCatalog_genes.gff >GeneCatalog_genes.bed
source_data.description: gff2bed is part of BEDOPS v2.4.25

components.data:
Here, we demonstrate how to make a logogram for matches to the GAL4 PWM within R.

The resulting logograms are shown and described at https://you.stonybrook.edu/labyrinthulomycetes/regulatory-element-discovery-in-labyrinthulomycete-genomes/
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Here, we demonstrate how to make a logogram for matches to the GAL4 PWM within R.

The resulting logograms are shown and described at https://you.stonybrook.edu/labyrinthulomycetes/regulatory-element-discovery-in-labyrinthulomycete-genomes/

components.data: R: Make a logogram for discovered motifs for a TF of interest
components.name: Section

source_data.section: R: Make a logogram for discovered motifs for a TF of interest

source_data.name:
library(seqLogo)
library(Biostrings)
library(data.table)
aur1 <- fread("output_directory/fimo.txt")
aur2 <- aur1[ which(aur1$pattern=='GAL4'), ]
aurGAL4 <- DNAStringSet(aur2$match)
pfm <- consensusMatrix(aurGAL4) 
pfm2 <- pfm[1:4,]
pfm3 <- prop.table(pfm2,2)
aurGAL4pwm <- makePWM(pfm3) 

pdf("GAL4_logo.pdf")
seqLogo(aurGAL4pwm)
dev.off()
source_data.description:
R version 3.3.2 (2016-10-31)
[1] data.table_1.10.0   Biostrings_2.42.1   XVector_0.14.0
[4] IRanges_2.8.1       S4Vectors_0.12.1    BiocGenerics_0.20.0
[7] seqLogo_1.40.0

fimo.txt is the output from fimo in step 6.
